elements.content: Mn(III) complexes of 1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-((2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)amino)ethane (H3L), mononuclear [Mn(L)(MeOH)(H2O)] (1) and amido-bridged one-dimensional [Mn(L)(H2O)]∞ (2), have been synthesized by the reaction of MnAc3·2H2O with H3L. Magnetic studies revealed that complex 2 exhibits intermetallic ferromagnetic coupling, which is the first one-dimensional high-spin Mn(III) complex with ferromagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Mn(III) complexes of 1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-((2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)amino)ethane (H3L), mononuclear [Mn(L)(MeOH)(H2O)] (1) and amido-bridged one-dimensional [Mn(L)(H2O)]∞ (2), have been synthesized by the reaction of MnAc3⋅2H2O with H3L. Magnetic studies revealed that complex 2 exhibits intermetallic ferromagnetic coupling, which is the first one-dimensional high-spin Mn(III) complex with ferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: The reaction of 1-(2-Hydroxybenzamido)-2-((2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)amino)ethane (H3L) with MnAc3·2H2O gave the monomeric [Mn(L)(MeOH)(H2O)] (1) and amido-bridged one-dimensional [Mn(L)(H2O)]∞ (2). The latter is the first one-dimensional high-spin Mn(III) complex with ferromagnetic property.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of 1-(2-Hydroxybenzamido)-2-((2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)amino)ethane (H3L) with MnAc3⋅2H2O gave the monomeric [Mn(L)(MeOH)(H2O)] (1) and amido-bridged one-dimensional [Mn(L)(H2O)]∞ (2). The latter is the first one-dimensional high-spin Mn(III) complex with ferromagnetic property.

elements.content: The magnetically anisotropic octahedral Mn(III) ion is important for producing single-molecule magnets (SMMs) or single-chain magnets (SCMs), and has been widely employed for the synthesis of SMMs and SCMs. Because a high-spin ground-state is a prerequisite for SMMs or SCMs, it is desirable to achieve ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(III) ions. Until now, most one-dimensional (1D) Mn(III) complexes exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior except a cyano-bridged 1D Mn(III) complex {[Mn(salen)][Mn(salen)(CN)2]}∞ that displays ferromagnetic behavior. In {[Mn(salen)][Mn(salen)(CN)2]}∞, the spin states of the alternate Mn(III) ions within the chains are different: low-spin and high-spin. Herein, we synthesized two new high-spin Mn(III) complexes of H3L (Scheme ), and the 1D complex shows unprecedented ferromagnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: The magnetically anisotropic octahedral Mn(III) ion is important for producing single-molecule magnets (SMMs) or single-chain magnets (SCMs), and has been widely employed for the synthesis of SMMs and SCMs. Because a high-spin ground-state is a prerequisite for SMMs or SCMs, it is desirable to achieve ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(III) ions. Until now, most one-dimensional (1D) Mn(III) complexes exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior except a cyano-bridged 1D Mn(III) complex {[Mn(salen)][Mn(salen)(CN)2]}∞ that displays ferromagnetic behavior. In {[Mn(salen)][Mn(salen)(CN)2]}∞, the spin states of the alternate Mn(III) ions within the chains are different: low-spin and high-spin. Herein, we synthesized two new high-spin Mn(III) complexes of H3L (Scheme ), and the 1D complex shows unprecedented ferromagnetic properties.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic View of the Reaction of H3L with MnAc3

elements.content: MnAc3·2H2O (268.1 mg, 1 mmol) and H3L (314.3 mg, 1 mmol) were mixed in 30 mL of methanol. After the addition of potassium t-butoxide (3 mmol), the solution was refluxed for 2 h, giving a brown solution and a small amount of precipitate. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness at room temperature. The brown powder was collected, which was extracted with MeCN (15 mL). The residual solid was dissolved in MeOH (15 mL). Evaporation of the MeOH solution gave brown strip single crystals. Slow evaporation of two solutions at room temperature gave the single crystals of 2 (rhombus) and 1 (strip), respectively. This shows that complex 2 is soluble in MeCN while complex 1 is insoluble in MeCN, and both compounds show good solubility in methanol. Yield: 40% (1) and 20% (2).
elements.clean_text: MnAc3⋅2H2O (268.1 mg, 1 mmol) and H3L (314.3 mg, 1 mmol) were mixed in 30 mL of methanol. After the addition of potassium t-butoxide (3 mmol), the solution was refluxed for 2 h, giving a brown solution and a small amount of precipitate. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness at room temperature. The brown powder was collected, which was extracted with MeCN (15 mL). The residual solid was dissolved in MeOH (15 mL). Evaporation of the MeOH solution gave brown strip single crystals. Slow evaporation of two solutions at room temperature gave the single crystals of 2 (rhombus) and 1 (strip), respectively. This shows that complex 2 is soluble in MeCN while complex 1 is insoluble in MeCN, and both compounds show good solubility in methanol. Yield: 40% (1) and 20% (2).

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of complex 1 is a neutral monomer (Figure ) with the formula of [Mn(L)(H2O)(CH3OH)]. Mn(III) ion is hexa-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms of L3−, and further two oxygen atoms of one MeOH and one H2O molecule. The Mn(III) ion exhibits an elongated octahedral geometry with two solvent molecules situated at axial positions. There is strong hydrogen bonding between the amido oxygen atom and the methanol oxygen atom of adjacent molecule [O(5)−O(1)#1 = 2.641 Å, O(5)−H(5)−O(1)#1 = 176.56°, #1: −x, −y, −z + 1]. Another important intermolecular contact involves the coordinating water molecules and the phenoxy and the methoxy oxygen atoms. Hence, intermolecular H-bonding connects adjacent molecules forming a supramolecular chain (). The nearest Mn−Mn separation is 4.990 Å.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of complex 1 is a neutral monomer (Figure ) with the formula of [Mn(L)(H2O)(CH3OH)]. Mn(III) ion is hexa-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms of L3-, and further two oxygen atoms of one MeOH and one H2O molecule. The Mn(III) ion exhibits an elongated octahedral geometry with two solvent molecules situated at axial positions. There is strong hydrogen bonding between the amido oxygen atom and the methanol oxygen atom of adjacent molecule [O(5)-O(1)#1 = 2.641 Å, O(5)-H(5)-O(1)#1 = 176.56°, #1: -x, -y, -z + 1]. Another important intermolecular contact involves the coordinating water molecules and the phenoxy and the methoxy oxygen atoms. Hence, intermolecular H-bonding connects adjacent molecules forming a supramolecular chain (). The nearest Mn-Mn separation is 4.990 Å.

elements.content: Structure of complex 1 (hydrogen atoms are not shown for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of complex 1 (hydrogen atoms are not shown for clarity).

elements.content: Compound 2 possesses 1D zigzag chain structure with alternating [Mn(L)(H2O)] groups connected by the amido oxygen bridges, as shown in Figure . The Mn(III) ions has an elongated octahedral coordination configuration with two imine nitrogen and two phenoxy oxygen atoms at the equatorial plane, and one water oxygen and the amido oxygen atom of adjacent [Mn(L)(H2O)] moiety situated at the axial sites. The axial Mn−O bond distances [2.3451(11) Å for Mn(1)−O(1W) and 2.2577(10) Å for Mn(1)−O(4)#1, #1: −x, y − 1/2, −z − 1/2] are longer than the equatorial ones. The amido oxygen atom coordinates to Mn(III) with the CO−Mn bond angle of 169.99(10)°. In the chain adjacent MnN2O2 equatorial coordination planes are nearly perpendicular and the corresponding dihedral angle is 82.5° (Figure and ). This arrangement is different from the amido-bridged 1D Mn(III) analogues [Mn(L1)(MeOH)] and [Mn(L2−4)(MeOH)] (H3L1 = 1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-((2-hydroxybenzylidene)amino)ethane, H3L = derivatives of 3-aza-4-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-hydroxyphenyl)-N-(2-hydroxyphenyl)but-3-enamide) with the dihedral angle of 51.6°, 69.3°, 71.0°, and 74.3°, respectively. The intrachain Mn···Mn separation of complex 2 is 6.330(1) Å, longer than that of 1D complexes [Mn(L1)(MeOH)] (5.828 Å) and [Mn(L2−4)(MeOH)] (6.035−6.120 Å).
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 possesses 1D zigzag chain structure with alternating [Mn(L)(H2O)] groups connected by the amido oxygen bridges, as shown in Figure . The Mn(III) ions has an elongated octahedral coordination configuration with two imine nitrogen and two phenoxy oxygen atoms at the equatorial plane, and one water oxygen and the amido oxygen atom of adjacent [Mn(L)(H2O)] moiety situated at the axial sites. The axial Mn-O bond distances [2.3451(11) Å for Mn(1)-O(1W) and 2.2577(10) Å for Mn(1)-O(4)#1, #1: -x, y - 1/2, -z - 1/2] are longer than the equatorial ones. The amido oxygen atom coordinates to Mn(III) with the CO-Mn bond angle of 169.99(10)°. In the chain adjacent MnN2O2 equatorial coordination planes are nearly perpendicular and the corresponding dihedral angle is 82.5° (Figure  and ). This arrangement is different from the amido-bridged 1D Mn(III) analogues [Mn(L1)(MeOH)] and [Mn(L2-4)(MeOH)] (H3L1 = 1-(2-hydroxybenzamido)-2-((2-hydroxybenzylidene)amino)ethane, H3L = derivatives of 3-aza-4-(3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-hydroxyphenyl)-N-(2-hydroxyphenyl)but-3-enamide) with the dihedral angle of 51.6°, 69.3°, 71.0°, and 74.3°, respectively. The intrachain Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separation of complex 2 is 6.330(1) Å, longer than that of 1D complexes [Mn(L1)(MeOH)] (5.828 Å) and [Mn(L2-4)(MeOH)] (6.035-6.120 Å).

elements.content: View of the zigzag chain structure of 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the zigzag chain structure of 2.

elements.content: The chains are linked by hydrogen bonds between the coordinating water atoms and the phenoxy oxygen and the methoxy oxygen atoms of adjacent chains giving rise to a 2D supramolecular layer (). The nearest interchain Mn···Mn separation is 4.935(1) Å, even shorter than the intrachain Mn···Mn distance (6.330(1) Å).
elements.clean_text: The chains are linked by hydrogen bonds between the coordinating water atoms and the phenoxy oxygen and the methoxy oxygen atoms of adjacent chains giving rise to a 2D supramolecular layer (). The nearest interchain Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separation is 4.935(1) Å, even shorter than the intrachain Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance (6.330(1) Å).

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2 have been measured on a SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 2.0−300 K, as shown in Figure . The room-temperature χm T value is 3.05 emu K mol−1 for complex 1 and 2.96 emu K mol−1 for complex 2, close to the spin-only value of 3.0 emu K mol−1 for high-spin Mn(III) with g = 2.0. The χm T value of complex 1 is nearly constant down to 50 K, and then gradually decreases. The fit to the Curie−Weiss law χm = C/(T − θ) gives the Weiss constant of θ = −3.82 K. Two factors are responsible for the magnetic properties of complex 1: zero-field splitting of high-spin Mn(III) and the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction. The latter should be due to the hydrogen bonding that links the Mn(III) monomers into supramolecular 1D chains. However, the magnetic properties of complex 2 are different: the χm T first gradually increases with the decrease of the temperature, reaching the maximum value of 3.20 emu K mol−1 at 26 K. Whereafter, χm T decreases, amounting to 0.659 emu K mol−1 K at 3 K. The magnetic data above 10 K obey the Curie−Weiss law, giving the Curie constant C = 2.96 emu K mol−1 and the Weiss constant θ = 2.3 K. This magnetic behavior is indicative of the presence of intrachain ferromagnetic coupling, and the drop of χm T should be due to the presence of zfs of Mn(III) and the interchain magnetic interaction.

The room-temperature χm T value is 3.05 emu K mol-1 for complex 1 and 2.96 emu K mol-1 for complex 2, close to the spin-only value of 3.0 emu K mol-1 for high-spin Mn(III) with g = 2.0. The χm T value of complex 1 is nearly constant down to 50 K, and then gradually decreases. The fit to the Curie-Weiss law χm = C/(T - θ) gives the Weiss constant of θ = -3.82 K. Two factors are responsible for the magnetic properties of complex 1: zero-field splitting of high-spin Mn(III) and the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction. The latter should be due to the hydrogen bonding that links the Mn(III) monomers into supramolecular 1D chains. However, the magnetic properties of complex 2 are different: the χm T first gradually increases with the decrease of the temperature, reaching the maximum value of 3.20 emu K mol-1 at 26 K. Whereafter, χm T decreases, amounting to 0.659 emu K mol-1 K at 3 K. The magnetic data above 10 K obey the Curie-Weiss law, giving the Curie constant C = 2.96 emu K mol-1 and the Weiss constant θ = 2.3 K. This magnetic behavior is indicative of the presence of intrachain ferromagnetic coupling, and the drop of χm T should be due to the presence of zfs of Mn(III) and the interchain magnetic interaction.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χm T for complexes 1 and 2. The line represents the best fit in the temperature range 10−300 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of χm T for complexes 1 and 2. The line represents the best fit in the temperature range 10-300 K.

elements.content: A linear chain assuming Heisenberg isotropic coupling according to Fisher’s expression for S = 2 was used to fit the magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 based on the Hamiltonian Ĥ = − J Σ i − 1 N − 1 Ŝ i Ŝ i + 1 taking into account the zero-field splitting (zfs) term (D). The eq was used, corrected by the mean-field approximation: χ m = χ chain / ( 1 − 2 z J ′ χ chain / N g 2 β 2 ) where z is the nearest coupling chains (z = 2 in this case). The satisfactory fitting results can only be reached down to 10 K, giving the parameters J = 1.81(2) cm−1, g = 1.98(1), D Mn = −7.1(5) cm−1, zJ′ = −0.98(1) cm−1, and R = 4.0 × 10−6. It is worth mentioning that this treatment is appropriate for the situation that zfs is dominant, and the magnetic coupling is the minor factor. The positive J value indicates the presence of intrachain ferromagnetic coupling. As far as we are aware, complex 2 is the first 1D Mn(III) complex with Mn(III)−Mn(III) ferromagnetic coupling. χ chain T = χ zfs 1 + u 1 − u u = coth [ J ′ S ( S + 1 ) k T ] − k T J S ( S + 1 ) χ zfs = ( χ ∥ + 2 χ ⊥ ) / 3 χ II = N g 2 β 2 k T · 2 e − x + 8 e − 4 x 1 + 2 e − x + 2 e − 4 x χ ⊥ = N g 2 β 2 k T · 6 x ( 1 − e − x ) + 4 3 x ( e − x − e − 4 x ) 1 + 2 e − x + 2 e − 4 x , x = D / k T

elements.content: The mechanism of ferromagnetic interaction between Mn(III) ions in complex 2 deserves investigation. For elongated octahedral Mn(III), the electronic configuration is (d xz )1(d yz )1(d xy )1(d z 2 )1 in order of increase in energy, and the highest d x 2− y 2 orbital is empty given the elongation axis is taken as the z direction. Previously reported 1D Mn(III) complexes with elongated octahedral Mn(III) geometry show intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling, which has been assumed to be due to the orbital overlap (superexchange) through the bridges. Because the bridging atoms are situated at the Jahn−Teller axis of Mn(III), the long axial MnIII-ligand bond distances should weaken the d z 2 − d z 2 overlap, resulting in weak AF interaction observed in the previously reported 1D Mn(III) complexes.
elements.clean_text: The mechanism of ferromagnetic interaction between Mn(III) ions in complex 2 deserves investigation. For elongated octahedral Mn(III), the electronic configuration is (d  xz )1(d  yz )1(d  xy )1(d  z 2 )1 in order of increase in energy, and the highest d  x 2-   y 2  orbital is empty given the elongation axis is taken as the z direction. Previously reported 1D Mn(III) complexes with elongated octahedral Mn(III) geometry show intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling, which has been assumed to be due to the orbital overlap (superexchange) through the bridges. Because the bridging atoms are situated at the Jahn-Teller axis of Mn(III), the long axial MnIII-ligand bond distances should weaken the d  z 2  - d  z 2  overlap, resulting in weak AF interaction observed in the previously reported 1D Mn(III) complexes.

elements.content: For complex 2, Mn(III) similarly exhibits a tetragonally elongated octahedral environment, indicating high-spin d 4 electronic configuration [(dxz )1(dyz )1(d xy )1(d z 2 )1] with the d x 2− y 2 orbital empty. The former three 3d orbitals are of π character, and d z 2 is of σ-type. Because of the Jahn−Teller elongation, the d z 2 orbital has been assumed to make a main contribution to the magnetic coupling. Therefore, the intrachain ferromagnetic coupling in complex 2 may be due to the orthogonal d z 2 orbitals of adjacent Mn(III) ions (Scheme a). Additionally, the orthogonality between d z 2 orbital and the three dπ orbitals [(d xz )(dyz )(dxy )] enhances the ferromagnetic coupling. Structural data of complex 2 show that the adjacent [Mn(L)(MeOH)] moieties are almost perpendicular to each other, and this strict orthogonality should result in ferromagnetic coupling between the adjacent Mn(III) ions. Another ferromagnetic contribution comes from the strong orbital overlap between the empty d x 2− y 2 orbital and the d z 2 orbital of two adjacent Mn(III) ions. As far as the amido-bridged Mn(III) 1D analogues are concerned, the distortion from strict orthogonality would bring about some degree of d z 2 − d z 2 orbital overlap, giving rise to weak antiferromagnetic interaction (Scheme b). This situation occurs in the carboxylate-bridged Mn(III) 1D compounds that exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: For complex 2, Mn(III) similarly exhibits a tetragonally elongated octahedral environment, indicating high-spin d 4 electronic configuration [(dxz )1(dyz )1(d  xy )1(d  z 2 )1] with the d  x 2-   y 2  orbital empty. The former three 3d orbitals are of π character, and d  z 2  is of σ-type. Because of the Jahn-Teller elongation, the d  z 2  orbital has been assumed to make a main contribution to the magnetic coupling. Therefore, the intrachain ferromagnetic coupling in complex 2 may be due to the orthogonal d  z 2  orbitals of adjacent Mn(III) ions (Scheme a). Additionally, the orthogonality between d  z 2  orbital and the three dπ orbitals [(d  xz )(dyz )(dxy )] enhances the ferromagnetic coupling. Structural data of complex 2 show that the adjacent [Mn(L)(MeOH)] moieties are almost perpendicular to each other, and this strict orthogonality should result in ferromagnetic coupling between the adjacent Mn(III) ions. Another ferromagnetic contribution comes from the strong orbital overlap between the empty d  x 2-   y 2  orbital and the d  z 2  orbital of two adjacent Mn(III) ions. As far as the amido-bridged Mn(III) 1D analogues are concerned, the distortion from strict orthogonality would bring about some degree of d  z 2  - d  z 2  orbital overlap, giving rise to weak antiferromagnetic interaction (Scheme b). This situation occurs in the carboxylate-bridged Mn(III) 1D compounds that exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.clean_text: 2  Orbital Overlap (d  z 2 ) of Two Adjacent Mn(III) Ions in 1D Amido-Bridged Mn(III) Complexes: (a) Strict Orthogonality in Complex 2; (b) Distortion from Orthogonality in [Mn(L x )(MeOH)] (x = 1-4)

elements.content: In conclusion, a new 1D amido-bridged Mn(III) complex shows interesting ferromagnetic coupling between adjacent Mn(III) ions, which is the first high-spin Mn(III) chain complex showing ferromagnetic property. The orthogonal magnetic orbitals of adjacent metal ions are responsible for the ferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a new 1D amido-bridged Mn(III) complex shows interesting ferromagnetic coupling between adjacent Mn(III) ions, which is the first high-spin Mn(III) chain complex showing ferromagnetic property. The orthogonal magnetic orbitals of adjacent metal ions are responsible for the ferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1 (C18H21MnN2O6): M t = 416.31, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 9.1082(18), b = 10.184(2), c = 11.642(2) Å, α = 65.43(3), β = 81.75(3), γ = 69.72(3)°, V = 921.3(3) Å3, Z = 2, ρcalcd = 1.501 g cm−3, μ(MoK α) = 0.754 mm−1, R1 = 0.0665, wR2 = 0.1246 (all data), T = 293 K. Crystal data for 2 (C17H17MnN2O5): M t = 384.27, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 10.550(2), b = 8.5260(17), c = 18.152(4) Å, β = 97.26(3)°, V = 1619.7(6) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalcd = 1.576 g cm−3, μ(MoK α) = 0.847 mm−1, R1 = 0.0256, wR2 = 0.0729 (all data), T = 293 K.

Two factors are responsible for the magnetic properties of complex 1: zero-field splitting of high-spin Mn(III) and the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction. The latter should be due to the hydrogen bonding that links the Mn(III) monomers into supramolecular 1D chains. However, the magnetic properties of complex 2 are different: the χm T first gradually increases with the decrease of the temperature, reaching the maximum value of 3.20 emu K mol−1 at 26 K. Whereafter, χm T decreases, amounting to 0.659 emu K mol−1 K at 3 K. The magnetic data above 10 K obey the Curie−Weiss law, giving the Curie constant C = 2.96 emu K mol−1 and the Weiss constant θ = 2.3 K. This magnetic behavior is indicative of the presence of intrachain ferromagnetic coupling, and the drop of χm T should be due to the presence of zfs of Mn(III) and the interchain magnetic interaction.

Crystal cell packing plots of complexes 1 and 2. An X-ray crystallographic file (CIF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

Anal. Calc. for C18H21MnN2O6 (1): C 51.93, H 5.08, N 6.73. Found: C 52.10, H 5.44, N 6.52. IR (KBr, cm−1): v 3450m (O−H), 1629s (CO), 1599s (C=N). Anal. Calc. for C17H19MnN2O6 (2·H2O): C, 50.74; H, 4.76; N, 6.97. Found: C, 50.15; H, 4.37; N, 6.98. IR (KBr, cm−1): v 3450m (O-H), 1629s (CO), 1599s (C=N).

Crystal data for 1 (C18H21MnN2O6): M t = 416.31, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 9.1082(18), b = 10.184(2), c = 11.642(2) Å, α = 65.43(3), β = 81.75(3), γ = 69.72(3)°, V = 921.3(3) Å3, Z = 2, ρcalcd = 1.501 g cm−3, μ(MoK α) = 0.754 mm−1, R1 = 0.0665, wR2 = 0.1246 (all data), T = 293 K. Crystal data for 2 (C17H17MnN2O5): M t = 384.27, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 10.550(2), b = 8.5260(17), c = 18.152(4) Å, β = 97.26(3)°, V = 1619.7(6) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalcd = 1.576 g cm−3, μ(MoK α) = 0.847 mm−1, R1 = 0.0256, wR2 = 0.0729 (all data), T = 293 K.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2 have been measured on a SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 2.0-300 K, as shown in Figure . The room-temperature χm T value is 3.05 emu K mol-1 for complex 1 and 2.96 emu K mol-1 for complex 2, close to the spin-only value of 3.0 emu K mol-1 for high-spin Mn(III) with g = 2.0. The χm T value of complex 1 is nearly constant down to 50 K, and then gradually decreases. The fit to the Curie-Weiss law χm = C/(T - θ) gives the Weiss constant of θ = -3.82 K. Two factors are responsible for the magnetic properties of complex 1: zero-field splitting of high-spin Mn(III) and the intermolecular antiferromagnetic interaction. The latter should be due to the hydrogen bonding that links the Mn(III) monomers into supramolecular 1D chains. However, the magnetic properties of complex 2 are different: the χm T first gradually increases with the decrease of the temperature, reaching the maximum value of 3.20 emu K mol-1 at 26 K. Whereafter, χm T decreases, amounting to 0.659 emu K mol-1 K at 3 K. The magnetic data above 10 K obey the Curie-Weiss law, giving the Curie constant C = 2.96 emu K mol-1 and the Weiss constant θ = 2.3 K. This magnetic behavior is indicative of the presence of intrachain ferromagnetic coupling, and the drop of χm T should be due to the presence of zfs of Mn(III) and the interchain magnetic interaction.

Crystal cell packing plots of complexes 1 and 2. An X-ray crystallographic file (CIF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Calc. for C17H19MnN2O6 (2⋅H2O): C, 50.74; H, 4.76; N, 6.97. Found: C, 50.15; H, 4.37; N, 6.98. IR (KBr, cm-1): v 3450m (O-H), 1629s (CO), 1599s (C=N).

Crystal data for 1 (C18H21MnN2O6): M t = 416.31, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 9.1082(18), b = 10.184(2), c = 11.642(2) Å, α = 65.43(3), β = 81.75(3), γ = 69.72(3)°, V = 921.3(3) Å3, Z = 2, ρcalcd = 1.501 g cm-3, μ(MoK α) = 0.754 mm-1, R1 = 0.0665, wR2 = 0.1246 (all data), T = 293 K. Crystal data for 2 (C17H17MnN2O5): M t = 384.27, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 10.550(2), b = 8.5260(17), c = 18.152(4) Å, β = 97.26(3)°, V = 1619.7(6) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalcd = 1.576 g cm-3, μ(MoK α) = 0.847 mm-1, R1 = 0.0256, wR2 = 0.0729 (all data), T = 293 K.
